name: 黃如瑩
objective: Objectives:It is the goal of the course to help  our  students  learn  English language and related cultural background knowledge through children and young adult literature with all its inherent cultural and educational significance.The treasure of literature, especially suitable and meaningful for children and teenagers, will be explored in a variety of learning activities in the class, including reading, discussions, role plays, creating picture books, and analyzing film adaptations with the aim to cultivate students’ full language skills and to enrich their cultural literacy in order to build a sound foundation for their future studies.
schedule:
I. syllabus
Week 1 
Introduction 
Focus One: The Heart of a Child
Week 2  
1. “Peter Rabbit" and “Benjamin Bunny” by Beatrix Potter 
2.  Important motifs in children’s story books
Week 3 
1.Picture books by Leo Leonni, Julia Donaldson, Quentin Blake, Jan Brett
2. Essential elements in children’s picture books 
Week 4 
1.The Little Prince and the theme of love
2. The Boy and the Horse animation film
Focus Two: The Heart of a Hero, Now and Then 
Week 5 
1. Beowulf
2. Greek Heroes: Hercules, Theseus, Perseus, Achilles, Odysseus 
3. Heroes today: Percy Jackson and the Olympians, Life of Pi
Week 6 
1.King Arthur Cycle: The Sword in the Stone, Merlin, The First Knight, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, The Knight’s Tale
2.The Harry Potter Series
Week 7 
1.The Grimm’s Tales
2.Modern versions of Grimm's Tales
Week 8
1.The Anderson’s Tales
2.Modern adaptations of  Anderson’s tales
Week 9 
1. "The Borrowers" series and Miyazaki's "Arietty"
2. Miyazaki 's "Spirited Away" 
Focus Three: The Heart of the Literary Masters 
Week 10 
1.The Wizard of Oz (Novel and film adaptation)
2. The theme of a hero’s journey and 
the great trope of life as a journey
Week 11 
1.The Habbit (Novel and film adaptation)
2. Important cultural and environmental issues in the Habbit
Week 12
1. Alice in the Wonderland
2. Through the Looking Glass (Novel and film adaptation)
Week 13 
1.Howl’s Moving Castle (Novel and film adaptation by Miyazaki)
2. The trilogy of Inkeart, Inkspell, and Inkdeath (by Cornelia Funke)
Week 14 
1.The Kite Runner (novel and film adaptation)
2. The theme of redemption in western culture
Focus Four: The Heart of Fantasy Literature
Week 15 
1. The Chronicles of Narnia
2. Religious themes and children’s coming of age
Week 16 
1.The Lord of the Rings Trilogy
2. The relevance of Tolkien’s world views to today’s world
Week 17 
1.The Earthsea Cycle 
2. Important elements in sci-fi fiction
Week 18 
Final project due

materials:
III. Reference books:
(1) The 20th-Century Children's Book Treasury. By Janet Schulman. New York: Alfred A. Knopf., 1998.
(2) The 20th-Century Children's Poetry Treasury. Selected by Jack Prelutsky. Illustrated by Meilo So. New York: Alfred A. Knopf., 1999.
(3) Beatrix Potter: The Complete Tales.  Authorized Edition by Frederick Warne. London: Penguin, 2002.
(4) The Family Storybook Treasury:  Tales of Laughter, Curiosity, and Fun. New York: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2011.
(5) Jan Brett’s Snowy Treasury. By Jan Brett. New York: Penguin, 2007.
(6) The Quentin Blake Treasury. By Quentin Blake.  London: Jonathan Cape, Random House, 2012.
